column9: Initiative from the undisclosed GRI (found by the coder but not mentioned in the GRI index table)

column6: Entities included in the organization's sustainability reporting
column7: REA's report included Simpology Pty Ltd, Realtair Pty Ltd, and Managed Platforms Pty Ltd.

column6: Reporting period, frequency, and contact point
column7: REA Group's FY23 Sustainability Report covers 1 July 2022 to 30 June 2023.

Where information reported in REA Group's FY22 Sustainability Report, which remained unchanged in the FY23 reporting period, the FY23 Report refers readers back to the FY22 Sustainability Report for further information.
KPMG provided external assurance for REA's report.

column6: Activities, value chain and other business relationships
column7: REA Group Ltd ACN is a leading digital property-centric business headquartered in Richmond, Victoria, Australia, with more than 3,300 people working to change how the world experiences property.
REA's Board currently comprises eight directors, including seven non-executive directors and one executive director.

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column13: All directors are appointed under formal letters of appointment. The letter of appointment sets out the key terms and conditions of the appointment of that director (including the time commitment envisaged, remuneration and other duties). The appointment letter also includes details regarding Committee responsibilities, directors' duties and responsibilities, Board performance evaluation, confidentiality of information, the Board's policy on obtaining independent advice, disclosure of interests and matters affecting independence, and entering into deeds of indemnity, insurance and access.
column20: Letter of appointment, director, Board performance

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column13: All new Board members are given an induction pack containing detailed information on REA Group and its operations. They can meet with existing Board members, relevant senior executives and external auditors.
column20: Induction pack, new Board member, senior executive

column6: Chair of the highest governance body
column7: Mr Hamish McLennan is the current Chairman of the Board.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
column7: REA Group's Chief People and Sustainability Officer provides the Company's annual Sustainability Report to the REA Group Board for approval before publishing.

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column13: REA's directors undertake a program of ongoing Director education, including office visits, presentations on various topics relevant to REA Group's business activities and briefings on material developments in laws, regulations and accounting standards. During FY23, the Board travelled to Singapore and India to meet with the PropertyGuru and REA India teams, respectively.
column20: Director education, office visit, business activity

column6: Role of the highest governance body in sustainability reporting
column8: Market Disclosure and External Communications Policy
column13: As a listed entity, REA is committed to complying with its continuous disclosure obligations under the ASX Listing Rules and the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) so that trading in REA's securities occurs in an orderly and informed market. Compliance with continuous disclosure obligations is managed through REA's Market Disclosure and External Communications Policy.
column20: Market Disclosure and External Communications Policy, continuous disclosure, ASX Listing Rule

column13: The Board assesses the independence of each director upon their appointment and annually after that. Directors are required on an ongoing basis to disclose to the Board relevant personal interests and conflicts of interest that may impact their actual or perceived independence. Upon any such disclosure, a director's independence is reassessed.

Employees are encouraged to raise concerns about behaviour that breaches the Code of Conduct to their manager or another appropriate person as soon as possible. Employees may call the independently operated SAFECALL (whistleblower) hotline if they feel uncomfortable speaking to someone at REA Group.

column6: Collective knowledge of the highest governance body
column13: The Board, with the guidance of the HR Committee, undertakes an annual review of the skills and experience of each director to assess the combined capabilities of the Board. The Board seeks to achieve a mix of skills and diversity that includes international, digital media, corporate management, and operational experience, as well as a deep understanding of the advertising industry and the nature of REA's customer relationships. The Board skills matrix provides a summary of relevant skills possessed by the directors.

column6: Evaluation of the performance of the highest governance body
column13: The performance of the Board, each Committee and individual directors is reviewed annually through a process facilitated by the Chairman of the Board. The Board performance review is undertaken with the objective of continuous governance improvement, identifying Board performance improvement opportunities and ensuring that the Board continues to operate effectively and efficiently.
column20: Performance review, continuous governance improvement, performance improvement

column13: REA's remuneration philosophy revolves around fair compensation based on individual contribution and market value. REA employs a remuneration framework that allows REA to compare positions internally and comprehend the correlation between job size and market-based pay.
column20: Remuneration philosophy, fair compensation, market value

column13: The CEO conducts an annual performance assessment of each Executive Leadership Team member's performance that involves an assessment of performance against specific and measurable financial and non-financial performance criteria. The outcomes of the CEO's assessment are independently considered and assessed by both the HR Committee and the Board (which considers any recommendations made by the HR Committee).
column20: Performance assessment, Executive Leadership Team, performance criteria

column7: "As we look to the year ahead, I'm excited by the ESG growth opportunities before us and have every confidence that the strength of our team and strategy will continue to deliver value for our shareholders, customers, consumers and the broader community."

column13: REA Group has a Code of Conduct that applies to all Board directors, employees, contractors, consultants and visitors working for REA Group worldwide. The Code of Conduct outlines REA Group's expectations for behaviour on a day-to-day basis. It guides how REA interacts and works with each other, customers, shareholders, the business and the community. It is fundamental to REA's culture and provides an important bridge between its values, policies and legal requirements.
column20: Code of Conduct, behaviour, value, policy

column13: REA Group has a Securities Trading Policy to assist REA Group employees and directors in complying with insider trading laws. Blackout periods apply from the end of every quarter until REA Group's financial results for the quarter, half year or full year (as applicable) are released to the market. During a blackout period, REA Group employees, directors, and close family members of employees and directors are not permitted to trade in REA Group securities.
column20: Securities Trading Policy, insider trading law, blackout period

column13: REA Group has a Risk Management Policy reflects industry best practices and is consistent with the International Standard ISO 31000:2018. During FY23, a detailed review of the REA Group Risk Management Policy was undertaken to identify any amendments necessary to improve how REA Group currently identifies, articulates, manages and reports on its risk and control environment to enable a more efficient and proactive application of risk management.
column20: Risk Management Policy, industry best practice, ISO 31000:2018

column6: Mechanisms for seeking advice and raising concern
column13: REA Group's Whistleblower Policy encourages current and former employees to report any actual or suspected conduct that may be fraudulent, corrupt, illegal, unethical or entail serious mismanagement of REA Group's resources. Appropriate internal and external channels have been implemented to ensure that any reports of wrongdoing are handled professionally and confidentially.

column7: REA Group conducts business following the laws and regulations of each country in which a REA Group business is located.
REA is a member of the Tech Council of Australia, the Real Estate Institute of Queensland, and the Diversity Council of Australia.

column13: REA Group's investor relations program includes scheduled briefings following quarterly, half-yearly and annual results reporting and during the AGM period. Other ad hoc briefings are held throughout the year, other than during blackout periods, with institutional investors, analysts and the media. These briefings and presentations allow two-way communication between REA Group and these stakeholders.
column20: Investor relations program, AGM, ad hoc briefing

column13: In FY23, REA's Financial Services rolled out a new customer relationship management (CRM) platform. Phase one included a client care program that delivers automated emails for mortgage broking customers at key points in their loan journey, such as for annual loan reviews and when fixed-rate loans are due to expire. The CRM also assists mortgage brokers in tracking workflows and delivering exceptional customer experiences.
column20: Customer relationship management platform, client care, mortgage broking customer

column13: REA Group undertook its second materiality assessment in FY22, with a wide range of key stakeholders participating in this process, including members of the Australian and Indian Executive Leadership Teams, shareholders, employees, proxy advisors, regulators, suppliers, consumers, customers, lenders, mortgage franchisees, mortgage clients and charity partners. REA Group expects the next materiality assessment to be undertaken in FY25.
